@jkbradley thanks for bringing this up. This issue does not cover the mxnet-mkl since it hasn't been released yet.

I attempted an experimental release for MKL version based on 0.9.3. During the process, I caught some issues (which were later fixed in #5085 etc), so I took down all the uploaded artifacts. MKL version will be available for the next release.

Edit the `_config.mk_` to set `USE_DIST_KVSTORE=1` is useless to make **mxnet** support distributed mode once you have compiled the file. You should 
 `make clean_all`
and then
 `make -j$(proc) USE_DIST_KVSTOE=1 USE_CUDA=1 USE_CUDA_PATH=/usr/local/cuda USE_BLAS=openblas USE_CUDNN=1` 
Just consult the official website
[http://mxnet.io/get_started/build_from_source.html](url)
If you are accessible  to Internet, it is really easy to get this problem done. If you aren't accessible to the Internet, you should check the `ps-lite/make/deps.mk`to install the dependent packages by hand. After you installation, you should edit `ps-lite/Makefile`to annotate `include make/deps.mk` which is in `line 25`. Then do the `make` operation above. I hope my experience will give your some help @darshanmaiya and this seems to be a small bug in **mxnet** @mli

@alanhuang1990 Can you clarify what you mean by 

> But the way to handle 'clip_gradient' is wrong.
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/optimizer_op-inl.h#L317
> 
> What implemented here is weight clipping, which should not be activated in 'clip_gradient'.

The code you refer to is implementing weight clipping, which is useful for certain scenarios such as training a network according to the [WGAN paper](https://arxiv.org/abs/1701.07875). It is independent of gradient clipping.

For mxnet, line 85
```
mx.initializer.Xavier()
```
This is useless, you must specify it in the create function
```
model = mx.model.FeedForward.create(
    ctx = mx.gpu(),    
    symbol=NN_model,       
    num_epoch = 100,     
    X=nd_iter, 
    eval_data=val_iter,
    learning_rate=0.0005, momentum=0.9,
    initializer=mx.initializer.Xavier()
)
```
Otherwise it's using default Uniform initializer

The problem isn't with the creation of your loss function. The issue is with how you're initializing your network weights. Specifically, it seems it's trying to initialize the values for your label variable, and it's complaining because it doesn't know an initialization strategy for a variable named label. Indeed, you shouldn't be initializing it, because it's a data input, not a weight :p 

So the question is, why did this happen? My suspicion is that you're using Module and didn't tell it the right name of the label variable. (I would need to see your additional code to know) Consider that this is in the init method signature for Module:
```
 def __init__(self, symbol, data_names=('data',), label_names=('softmax_label',),
                 logger=logging, context=ctx.cpu(), work_load_list=None,
                 fixed_param_names=None, state_names=None):
```
Note the default argument ` label_names=('softmax_label',)`. If you didn't set this value, then that's your problem, because in your case, your label variable is named 'label', not 'softmax_label'. Because it doesn't know that 'label' is the name of your label, it think it's a value to optimize, tries to initialize its value, and then complains because there is no defined strategy for parameters with the naming pattern 'label'.

tl;dr: do this:
```
mod = mx.module.Module(loss, ..., label_names=('label',), ...)
```

P.S. I highly recommend that your final symbol group the prediction value with the loss, otherwise you'll only be able to get the output of the loss and not what it predicts :p That is,

```
final_out = mx.sym.Group([mx.sym.BlockGrad(out), loss])
```

(The block grad is used because there is no top gradient for the prediction and you don't want the gradients to be wrt it)

thanks @Yangqing for the headup, it was fixed in the dmlc-core version of the code https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/master/include/dmlc/thread_local.h

The thread_local header in mxnet repo seems to be some legacy code that should be removed @piiswrong

Um https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/master/include/dmlc/thread_local.h#L26 the pragma should be an error() instead of message(), because the underlying storage is still not freeing per-thread when `DMLC_CXX11_THREAD_LOCAL` is not set, right?
LGTM,

Well, we fallback to the kinda of thread local version that de-allocates when program exits, which is not the ideal thing to do, but allow the user user with old systems to still use a degraded version

For Mac users, actually thread_local is properly supported in xcode8 https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/.travis.yml#L9

Apple allows use this in my mind, if you upgrade to xcode 8.0

@jiajiechen Thanks for your quick reply.
can you describe the log? What is show degraded perf?

```
    def update(self):
        """Update parameters according to the installed optimizer and the gradients computed
        in the previous forward-backward batch.
        """
        assert self.binded and self.params_initialized and self.optimizer_initialized

        self._params_dirty = True
        if self._update_on_kvstore:
            _update_params_on_kvstore(self._exec_group.param_arrays,
                                      self._exec_group.grad_arrays,
                                      self._kvstore)
        else:
            _update_params(self._exec_group.param_arrays,
                           self._exec_group.grad_arrays,
                           updater=self._updater,
                           num_device=len(self._context),
                           kvstore=self._kvstore)
```
This is update method of module. You can override it to do extra work when updating.
